original_title: Open VSX Supply Chain Attack Used Compromised Dev Account to Spread GlassWorm
selection_reasoning: This supply chain attack demonstrates the vulnerability of developer ecosystems and the trust placed in established contributors. The use of legitimate credentials and established extensions makes this a compelling story about reputation weaponization and the corruption of collaborative communities.

field_note.title: The Merchant's False Seal
field_note.subtitle: How established reputation becomes a weapon against the very community that created it
field_note.excerpt: Trust earned over seasons can be spent in a single moment to devastating effect.
field_note.epigraph: A merchant's seal, once respected, can sign contracts that destroy the very market that honored it
body_paragraphs: In the great trading halls where artificers share their craft, reputation is the most valuable currency. Merchants who have delivered quality goods season after season earn the trust of buyers who no longer examine each offering with suspicion. Their seal upon a package becomes guarantee enough - a shorthand for quality built through consistent service.

This moon brought disturbing news from the extension markets, where shadow weavers corrupted the credentials of an established merchant to spread a malignant enchantment called GlassWorm. The attack was particularly insidious because it leveraged not stolen goods, but stolen trust - using legitimate merchant credentials to distribute corrupted versions of four well-regarded tools.

The corruption followed the familiar pattern of parasitic magic: the infected extensions maintained their original functionality while secretly harboring additional enchantments designed to spread further corruption. Users received what appeared to be routine updates to trusted tools, never suspecting they were also accepting a persistent shadow into their domains.

What makes this incident particularly troubling is how it weaponizes the collaborative nature of our modern craft. The extension markets function on shared trust - developers contribute improvements, and users benefit from this collective effort. When that trust is corrupted, it threatens not just individual users but the entire ecosystem of cooperation.

The merchants of the trading hall responded quickly, removing the corrupted offerings and alerting users to the contamination. Yet the fundamental challenge remains: in a world built on shared trust and collaborative creation, how do we verify the integrity of each contribution without destroying the very efficiency that makes such collaboration valuable? The answer may lie in better ward-weaving around our most trusted seals.
